The accompanying ground-plan is reduced from drawings made by David Bryee, Esq., R.S.A.‚ Architect, in 1854, when the church was at length rcsolvcd to be restored. This was accomplished, chiefly at the expense of the Duke of Buccleuch‚ under Mr. Bryce’s directions, the walls having been ⁴ cased,’ the interior arrangements altered and rendered more commodious, and a new steeple and spire erected in place of the com- parativcly modern square tower and steeple. In this restoration the eastern portion or ehanceL which, as not required for public service, had been separated from the church by a partition wall, for at least two centuries, was fortunately allowed to remain untouched in its old ruinous state. The entrance or door-way to the south, with the walls and buttresses, being still very entire, it is most desirable that this portion of the building should not be allowed by neglect to go to destruction, which might be avoided were a light roof thrown over it, the windows opened up and glazed, the weeds and rank grass cleared out, and care especially taken to preserve the old Douglas monument with its recumbent figures, which at present is ex- posed to irreparable injury.
